questionContent.questionText:
1. use of drugs in the treatment of disease [chemotherapy]

2. study of new drug synthesis [medicinal chemistry]

3. study of how drugs interact with their target molecules [molecular pharmacology]

4. study of the harmful effects of drugs [toxicology]

5. study of drug effects in the body [pharmacodynamics]

6. measurement of drug absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion over a period of time [pharmacokinetics ]

instructions.instructions: Name the pharmacologic specialty based on its description as given.

readingPart.reading:
antidotepharmacisttoxicologist
chemical namepharmacologisttrade (brand) name
Food and Drug AdministrationPhysicians' Desk ReferenceUnited States Pharmacopeia
generic name

questionContent.questionText:
1. Specialist in the study of the harmful effects of drugs on the body is a/an [toxicologist].

2. Agent given to counteract harmful effects of a drug is a/an [antidote].

3. Government agency with legal responsibility for enforcing proper drug manufacture and clinical use is [(U.S.) Food and Drug Administration].

4. The [trade (brand) name] is the commercial name for a drug.

5. The [chemical name] is the complete chemical formula for a drug.

6. The [generic name] is the legal noncommercial name for a drug.

7. Professional who prepares and dispenses drugs is a/an [pharmacist].

8. Specialist (MD or PhD) who studies the properties, uses, and side effects of drugs is a/an [pharmacologist].    

9. Reference book listing drug products is [Physicians’ Desk Reference].

10. Authoritative listing of drugs, formulas, and preparations that sets a standard for drug manufacturing and dispensing is [United States Pharmacopeia ]

instructions.instructions: Match the general pharmacology terms with the deﬁnitions/descriptions that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. administered via suppository or ﬂuid into the anus [rectal]

2. administered via vapor or gas into the nose or mouth [inhalation]

3. administered under the tongue [sublingual]

4. applied locally on skin or mucous membrane [topical]

5. injected via syringe under the skin or into a vein, muscle, or body cavity [parenteral]

6. given by mouth and absorbed through the stomach or intestinal wall [oral ]

instructions.instructions: Name the route of drug administration based on its description as given.

readingPart.reading: within a vein
within a sheath (membranes around the spinal cord or brain)
an agent that works against infection
an agent that works against itching
particles of drug suspended in air and inhaled
within a muscle
under the skin
within a cavity
physical and psychological dependence on a drug
amount of drug administered
lack of beneﬁcial response
desired and beneficial effect of a drug
exact timing and frequency of drug administration
prolonged use of a drug that may lead to physiologic need for its actions in the body

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. intravenous [blood transfusions]

2. rectal [suppositories]

3. oral [tablets and capsules]

4. topical [lotions, creams, ointments]

5. inhalation [aerosol medications]

6. intrathecal [lumbar puncture]

7. intramuscular [deep injection, usually in buttock]

8. intradermal [skin testing for allergy ]

instructions.instructions: Match the routes of drug administration with the medications or procedures in the dropdown.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Combination of two drugs is greater than the total effects of each drug by itself: [synergism/potentiation]

2. Combination of two drugs that is equal to the sum of the effects of each: [additive action]

3. Effects of a given drug dose become less as treatment continues, and larger and larger doses must be given to achieve the desired effect: [tolerance]

4. An unexpected effect that may appear in a patient after administration of a drug: [idiosyncrasy]

5. Two drugs give less than an additive effect (action): [antagonistic ]

instructions.instructions: For the following descriptions of drug actions, supply the word that ﬁts the description.

readingPart.reading: an agent that inhibits or kills germ life (microorganisms)
an agent that relieves the symptoms of depression
an agent that blocks the action of histamine and relieves allergic symptoms
an agent that relieves pain
an agent that prevents blood clotting
an agent that reduces or eliminates sensation
An agent used to prevent or treat diabetes mellitus
an agent (mildly hypnotic) that relaxes and calms nervousness
an agent that excites and promotes activity
a drug used to control anxiety and severe disturbances of behavior

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms that describe classes of drugs.

questionContent.questionText:
1. antihistamine [anaphylactic shock]

2. analgesic [nonsteroidal anti-inﬂammatory drug]

3. antidiabetic [insulin]

4. anticoagulant [heparin]

5. antibiotic [penicillin or erythromycin]

6. stimulant [caffeine or amphetamines]

7. sedative-hypnotic [benzodiazepine]

8. tranquilizer [phenothiazine]

instructions.instructions: Match the term with the associated term in the dropdown.

readingPart.reading: drug that blocks the action of epinephrine at sites of receptors of heart muscles, blood vessels, and bronchial tubes (antihypertensive, antianginal, and antiarrhythmic)
a drug that produces male sexual characteristics
a hormone from the adrenal glands that reduces inﬂammation and raises blood sugar
a drug that blocks the entrance of calcium into heart muscle and blood vessel walls (antianginal, antiarrhythmic, and antihypertensive)
a hormone that produces female sexual characteristics
a drug that neutralizes acid in the stomach
a drug that relieves constipation
a drug that prevents nausea and vomiting
a drug that opens air passages
an agent that produces sleep
a drug that reduces the volume of blood and lowers blood pressure
a drug that reduces cholesterol levels (treats hypercholesterolemia)

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. anticonvulsant [epilepsy]

2. anticoagulant [thrombosis and embolism]

3. antacid [epigastric discomfort]

4. progestins [abnormal uterine bleeding caused by hormonal imbalance]

5. antibiotic [streptococcal pharyngitis]

6. ACE inhibitor [congestive heart failure and hypertension]

7. bronchodilator [asthma]

8. antihistamine [anaphylactic shock]

9. tranquilizer [severe behavior disturbances and anxiety]

10. analgesic [myalgia and neuralgia ]

instructions.instructions: Match the type of drug with the condition it treats in the dropdown.

questionContent.questionText:
1. agent that reduces fever: anti[pyretic]

2. agent that reduces itching: anti[pruritic]

3. habit-forming analgesic: [narco]tic

4. two drugs cause an effect greater than the sum of each alone: syn[ergism]

5. antibiotic derived from a red mold: [erythro]mycin

6. legal nonproprietary name of a drug: [generic] name  

7. factor in a patient’s condition that prevents the use of a particular drug: contra[indication]

8. drug that produces an absence of sensation or feeling: an[esthetic]

instructions.instructions: Complete the following terms based on deﬁnitions given.

readingPart.reading:
ACE inhibitorantidepressantdiuretic
anestheticantiestrogenNSAID
antibioticantihistamineoral antidiabetic
anticonvulsantantiviralSERM

questionContent.questionText:
1. Cephalosporins (such as cefuroxime and cefprozil) and penicillins are examples of [antibiotic] drugs.

2. Advil (ibuprofen) is an example of a/an [NSAID].

3. Tegretol (carbamazepine) and Dilantin (phenytoin) are examples of a/an [anticonvulsant] drug.

4. Zovirax (acyclovir) and Crixivan (indinavir) are both types of a/an [antiviral] drug.

5. Nolvadex (tamoxifen), used to treat estrogen receptor–positive breast cancer in women, is an example of a/an [antiestrogen] drug.

6. Patients with high blood pressure may need Vasotec (enalapril) or Zestril (lisinopril). Both of these are examples of a/an [ACE inhibitor].

7. Metformin and Avandia (rosiglitazone) are two types of [oral antidiabetic for type 2 diabetes] drugs.

8. Evista (raloxifene), used to treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women, is an example of a selective estrogen receptor modulator, or [SERM].

9. Elavil (amitriptyline) and Prozac (ﬂuoxetine) are two types of a/an [antidepressant] drug.

10. If you have an allergy, your doctor may prescribe Allegra (fexofenadine), which is a/an [antihistamine] drug.

11. Two agents that reduce the amount of ﬂuid in the blood and thus lower blood pressure are Lasix (furosemide) and Aldactone (spironolactone). These are [diuretic] drugs.

12. Xylocaine (lidocaine) and Pentothal (thiopental) are examples of a/an [anesthetic] drug.

instructions.instructions: Select from the list of drug terms to complete the following sentences.  Consult Appendix IV (Drugs) for help with this exercise.

questionContent.questionText:
1. NSAID [nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug]

2. p.r.n. [as needed]

3. q.i.d. [four times a day/four times daily/4 times a day]

4. ad lib [freely as desired/freely/as desired/freely, as desired]

5. t.i.d. [three times a day/three times daily/3 times a day]

6. mg [milligram]

7. c̅  [with]

8. s̅ [without] 

9. NPO [nothing by mouth]

10. p.c. [after meals]

11. b.i.d. [twice a day/two times daily/2 times a day/two times a day]

12. q.h. [every hour]

13. PO [by mouth]

14. q [every]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following abbreviations.

prompt.text: 1 tab PO q.i.d. p.c. and h.s.

readingPart.reading: take one tablet by mouth, four times a day, after meals and at bedtime
administer 15 to 60 milligrams intramuscularly, every 4-6 hours
take two capsules by mouth at bedtime
place one tablet under the tongue, as needed
apply to the skin, at bedtime as needed

questionContent.questionText:
1. After his heart attack, Bernie was supposed to take many drugs, including diuretics and a/an [anticoagulant /progestin/laxative] to prevent blood clots.

2. Estelle was always anxious and had a hard time sleeping. Dr. Max suggested that a mild [tranquilizer/antacid/anticonvulsant] would help her relax and concentrate on her work.

3. During chemotherapy Helen was very nauseated. Dr. Cohen prescribed an [antiemetic/antihypertensive/antianginal] to relieve her symptoms of queasy stomach.

4. The two antibiotics worked together and were therefore [synergistic/idiosyncratic/generic] in killing the bacteria in Susan’s bloodstream.

5. The label warned that the drug might impair ﬁne motor skills. It listed the [side effects/antidote/pharmacodynamics] of the sedative.

6. After receiving the results of Judy’s sputum culture, her physician, an expert in [infectious disease/endocrinology/cardiology], recommended Biaxin and other [antibiotics/antihistamines/antidepressants] to combat the Mycobacterium avium complex disease in her [lungs/heart/thyroid gland].

7. Our dog, Eli, has had seizures since he was hit by a car last year. The veterinarian currently prescribes phenobarbital, an [anticonvulsant/anticoagulant/antinauseant], 45 mg b.i.d. [twice a day/every other day/every evening].

8. To control his type 1 [diabetes/heart disease/asthma], David gives himself daily injections of [insulin/oral drugs/aromatase inhibitors].

9. Many students who want to stay awake to study are taking [stimulants/sedatives/tranquilizers] containing [caffeine/lithium/butabarbital].

10. Shelly’s wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath when she is stressed and exposed to animal dander all pointed to a diagnosis of [asthma/pneumonia/heart disease], which required treatment with steroids and [bronchodilators/antivirals/diuretics].

instructions.instructions: Select the terms that best complete the meaning of the sentences.
